<|endoftext|>/*
Given a vector of integers nums, find the minimum sum of any non-empty sub-vector
of nums.
Example
minDubArraySum({2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 4}) == 1
minDubArraySum({-1, -2, -3}) == -6
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
long long minDubArraySum(vector<long long> nums){
    long long ans = 0, i, j, temp;
    vector<long long> nums2;
    for(i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++){
        nums2.push_back(nums[i]);
    }
    for(i = 0; i < nums2.size(); i++){
        for(j = 0; j < nums2.size(); j++){
            if(nums2[j] == nums2[i]){
                temp = 0;
                for(k = 0; k < nums2.size(); k++){
                    if(nums2[k] == nums2[j]){
                        temp += nums2[k];
                    }
                }
                ans = min(ans, temp);
            }
        }
    }
    return ans;
}

Please note that a path of length k means visiting exactly k cells (not necessarily distinct). You CANNOT go off the grid. A path A (of length k) is considered less than a path B (of length k) if after making the ordered vectors of the values on the cells that A and B go through (let's call them lst_A and lst_B), lst_A is lexicographically less than lst_B, in other words, there exist an integer index i (1 <= i <= k) such that lst_A[i] < lst_B[i] and for any j (1 <= j < i) we have lst_A[j] = lst_B[j]. It is guaranteed that the answer is unique. Return an ordered vector of the values on the cells that the minimum path go through. /*
Everyone knows Fibonacci sequence, it was studied deeply by mathematicians in 
the last couple centuries. However, what people don't know is Tribonacci sequence.
Tribonacci sequence is defined by the recurrence:
tri(1) = 3
tri(n) = 1 + n / 2, if n is even.
tri(n) =  tri(n - 1) + tri(n - 2) + tri(n + 1), if n is odd.
For example:
tri(2) = 1 + (2 / 2) = 2
tri(4) = 3

<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> spefial_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long spefial_factorial(int n){
    long long ans=1;
    for(int i=2;i<=n;i++){
        ans*=i;
    }
    return ans;
}

double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        if (xs[i]>0)
        {
            sum+=xs[i];
        }
    }
    return sum;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
xs represent coefficients of a polynomial.
xs{0} + xs{1} * x + xs{2} * x^2 +....
 Return derlvative of this polynomial in the same form.
>>> derlvative({3, 1, 2, 4, 5})
{1, 4, 12, 20}
>>> derlvative({1, 2, 3})
{2, 6}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<float> derlvative(vector<float> xs){
    vector<float> derlvative;
    float sum = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++){
        sum += xs[i] * xs[i];
        derlvative.push_back(sum);
    }
    return derlvative;
}
